author: Julie J
title: Celestia (TIA) Faces Steep Decline Amid Growing Bearish Pressure
text:
Celestia (TIA), a cryptocurrency that has been experiencing a steady decline in recent weeks, has taken a sharp downturn, falling 15% in just the last 24 hours. The drop adds to an ongoing trend, with the digital asset now down nearly 40% over the past month. While its market capitalization still stands at $2.2 billion, technical indicators suggest that Celestia is under increasing bearish pressure, and the path forward remains uncertain.
Bearish Signals Mount The most concerning development for Celestia is the recent formation of a death cross, a widely recognized bearish pattern in technical analysis. This happens when a short-term moving average crosses below a long-term moving average, signaling a potential downturn. The death cross typically signals the start of a prolonged downtrend, which is what many traders are bracing for now.
Alongside this, the Average Directional Index (ADX) has been rising, moving from 31.2 to 35.2 in the past 24 hours. The ADX measures the strength of a trend, and values above 25 indicate a strong trend. With the current reading above 35, the market is signaling that the downward trend is not only strong but likely to continue unless significant buying pressure emerges.
Weakening Bullish Momentum The Directional Movement Index (DMI), which tracks the buying and selling pressure in the market, further emphasizes the prevailing bearish sentiment. The +DI, which represents buying pressure, has dropped sharply from 22.2 to 11.3, suggesting that bullish momentum has weakened considerably. On the flip side, the -DI, which represents selling pressure, has risen from 14.3 to 33.3, indicating that sellers are firmly in control.
This growing disparity between buying and selling pressure suggests that the market is firmly in a downtrend, making it difficult for Celestia to break free from the current downward momentum without a significant reversal.
Ichimoku Cloud Confirms Bearish Trend Looking at the Ichimoku Cloud, a popular technical analysis tool, the bearish outlook for Celestia is reinforced. The price of TIA is currently trading well below the cloud, indicating a strong downtrend. The cloud itself, formed by the Senkou Span A and Senkou Span B, shows resistance above the price, making a recovery seem less likely at this stage.
Additionally, the Tenkan-sen (blue line) has diverged downward from the Kijun-sen (orange line), a sign that the bearish momentum is gaining strength. The Chikou Span, the green lagging line, is also positioned below the price and the cloud, further confirming the negative sentiment in the market.
For any recovery to take place, Celestia would need to break back above the cloud. However, with the current technical indicators showing little signs of a reversal, the prospect of a recovery seems slim.
Key Support at $4.54: Can It Hold? At present, Celestia is holding above a crucial support level at $4.54. This price level has served as a key line of defense for the cryptocurrency, preventing further declines. However, if this support is breached, the price could quickly fall toward the next major support level at $4.10.
A drop below $4.10 could signal a deeper correction, potentially dragging the price down further. The next significant support lies at $4, but for now, traders are closely monitoring the $4.54 level to see if it can hold.
What Lies Ahead for Celestia? Celestia‚Äôs future largely depends on whether it can maintain its support at $4.54 or if further bearish pressure will push the price lower. The market sentiment remains negative, and unless there is a substantial shift in buying activity, a further decline towards $4.10 seems likely.
However, if Celestia can regain momentum and push past resistance at $5.50, a recovery may be on the horizon. For now, though, the outlook remains bleak, and traders will need to watch for any signs of a shift in momentum before making any significant moves.
In conclusion, while the bearish trend for Celestia is undeniable, the next few days could be critical. If the price holds at $4.54, there may be a glimmer of hope for a reversal. However, a fall below this level could see Celestia continue its downward slide, possibly testing the $4.10 level in the near future.

author: Emma Ogao, ABC News
title: Nearly eight million displaced by war in Sudan: UN
text:
(LONDON) -- Nearly eight million people have been displaced by the war in Sudan as the conflict enters its 10th month, the United Nation has announced.
The conflict, which erupted on April 15, 2023, between the Rapid Support Forces Paramilitary group (RSF) and the Sudanese Army (SAF) after weeks of tensions linked to planned civilian rule, has killed at least 12,000 people according to the U.N.
Local groups, however, say the true toll is likely much higher than that.
‚ÄúI heard stories of heartbreaking loss of family, friends, homes and livelihoods in the midst of this despair,‚Äù said U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees, Filippo Grandi, speaking as he concluded his three-day visit to Ethiopia. ‚ÄúWithout further donor support, it will be extremely difficult to deliver much-needed help to those who need it most.‚Äù
Since April 2023, over 1.5 million people have fled to neighboring nations, with more than 500,000 fleeing into the border country of Chad, says the U.N. -- 86% of whom are women and children.
A further 100,000 people have crossed into Ethiopia and, in South Sudan, an estimated 1,500 refugees flow into it daily.
Aid organizations tell ABC News the situation is "dire," with nearly 25 million people -- almost 50% of Sudan‚Äôs total population -- in need of humanitarian aid as humanitarian access remains a "major issue" and health systems "near collapse."
U.N. Chief Fillipo Grandi has called on further "urgent" and "additional" support to meet their needs.
As the war continues, International Criminal Court (ICC) Prosecutor Karim Khan this week announced the ICC had "grounds to believe" war crimes under the Rome Statute are being committed in Darfur by both the RSF and SAF.
‚ÄúI can confirm to the council that we are collecting a very significant body of material, information and evidence that is relevant to those particular crimes,‚Äù Khan said speaking at the United Nations Security Council (UNSC). ‚ÄúThe situation is dire by any metric."
The impact of the war has been devastating as "profound" damage has ravaged "nearly every sector" of the northeast African nation. Many civilian homes continued to be occupied by militia groups, while civilian jewelry, cars and other items have been looted and often smuggled into neighboring countries.
As international demands for a cessation of hostilities continue, senior leaders from the SAF and RSF are reported to have met three times this month in Bahrain, attended by officials from Egypt and the United Arab Emirates.
‚ÄúWe want to see both parties return to the negotiating table, we want to see a ceasefire that is actually adhered to and we want to see both parties to this conflict stop their brutal attacks on civilians and actually take actions that are in the interests of the people of Sudan,‚Äù said U.S. State Department Spokesperson Matthew Miller.

Aggregazione dell‚ÄôAou di Cagliari e del Brotzu: la nuova Azienda unica si chiamer√† ‚ÄúAou Brotzu‚Äù, comprender√† anche l‚ÄôOncologico e il Microcitemico, e avr√† anche un‚Äôarticolazione denominata ‚ÄúOspedale dei bambini‚Äù che svolger√† la funzione di coordinamento delle rete pediatrica e neonatologica regionale.
Contestualmente alla creazione dell‚ÄôAou Brotzu √® previsto l‚Äôavvio del percorso finalizzato al riconoscimento ministeriale di Irccs, Istituto di ricovero e cura a carattere scientifico, per le aree Oncologia e Pediatria. Lo stesso percorso √® previsto per l‚ÄôAou di Sassari, per l‚Äôarea Cardiologia-Pneumologia. A iter concluso, nei due Irccs, al direttore generale, al collegio di direzione, al collegio sindacale e all‚Äôorgano di indirizzo, si aggiunger√† anche un Direttore scientifico.
Ancora: il ‚ÄúMarino‚Äù di Alghero verr√† trasferito dall‚ÄôAou di Sassari alla Asl 1.
Tutto questo dal 1¬∞ gennaio 2025.
Il provvedimento
Sono i punti principali del disegno di legge ‚ÄúDisposizioni urgenti di adeguamento dell‚Äôassetto organizzativo e istituzionale del sistema sanitario regionale‚Äù che sta provocando le prime scintille di quella che un consigliere regionale ha preannunciato come una ‚Äúguerra santa‚Äù.
Il fatto √® che ieri in Aula, mentre si dibatteva di eolico, speculazione e sacco dell‚ÄôIsola, insomma di una misura fondamentale per il futuro della nostra terra, alcuni esponenti dell‚Äôopposizione hanno gridato allo scandalo perch√© questa ‚ÄúRiforma‚Äù ‚Äì a quanto sembra partorita in seno a una ristrettissima cerchia di persone vicine alla presidente Todde, tanto che anche la maggior parte dei componenti della maggioranza l‚Äôavrebbe vista soltanto a cose fatte ‚Äì ha iniziato a girare su whatsapp, ‚Äúinoltrata molte volte‚Äù.
L'opposizione
¬´Una cosa seria che gira cos√¨, durante la discussione sulla legge per la salvaguardia del paesaggio e dei beni paesaggistici e ambientali. √à un fatto molto grave¬ª, stigmatizza Antonello Peru (Sardegna al Centro 20Venti). ¬´Da diverse persone che non siedono in quest'Aula, ho ricevuto via whatsapp la relazione al disegno di legge e anche la bozza. Questo √® un fatto gravissimo e preoccupante per le prerogative di questo Consiglio regionale¬ª, sottolinea Paolo Truzzu, capogruppo di Fdi. ¬´Chiedo di sapere se questa √® una legge gi√† approvata che la Giunta vuole proporre al Consiglio, o se sia in approvazione. √à necessario convocare una conferenza di capigruppo alla presenza dell'assessore. A una prima occhiata mi fa pensare all‚Äôennesimo poltronificio¬ª.
¬´Proposta operativa¬ª
Francesco Agus, capogruppo dei Progressisti (che nei giorni scorsi hanno detto con chiarezza che la gestione della Sanit√† non sta andando per niente bene e non si pu√≤ aspettare oltre per un cambio di passo) sottolinea: ¬´A quanto so si tratta di una bozza informale, non approvata in Giunta e non condivisa con i gruppi consiliari. Insomma, una proposta operativa aperta, che per√≤ non appare in grado di dare le risposte che servono in questa fase. Oggi dobbiamo concentrarci sulle urgenze: la crisi dei pronto soccorso, la cura dei pazienti cronici e l‚Äôabnorme aumento delle liste d‚Äôattesa, evitando nel breve periodo ogni cambiamento potenzialmente traumatico¬ª.
In tarda serata, ecco la nota anonima da ‚Äúfonti della maggioranza‚Äù: ¬´A scanso di equivoci affermiamo che non c‚Äô√® stata nessuna mancanza di rispetto. L‚Äôobiettivo della Giunta e della maggioranza √® di rimettere in sesto la sanit√† sarda, tutelare i cittadini e rimettere in moto una macchina enormemente danneggiata durante i 5 anni del governo di centrodestra. Non √® che i fastidi delle opposizioni nascono perch√© la Giunta Todde non accetter√† pi√π interferenze della politica?¬ª.

title: The Big Question: What's a book you've read that changed the way you think about the world? | New Hampshire Public Radio
text: The Big Question: What's a book you've read that changed the way you think about the world? Books can transport us to other worlds, or expose us to new information and perspectives we hadn‚Äôt thought of before. They can spark a lifelong passion for reading or open up fresh conversations with the people in our lives. So, for this month‚Äôs Big Question we asked you: 'What‚Äôs a book you‚Äôve read that changed the way you think about the world?‚Äô Here‚Äôs what some of you said: Megan - Enfield, NH: My book is ["The Second Shift" by Arlie Hochschild](https://www.penguinrandomhouse.com/books/310593/the-second-shift-by-arlie-hochschild-with-anne-machung/9780143120339/). The book summarizes the author's research on task division between married couples in the home. The research in this book that was so impactful to me shows male partners consistently demonstrate no commitment to task equality. When I was a young mother, I was constantly angry about the vastly disproportionate share of work I did. I felt like a second class citizen in my own home. Every major point the author made, she verified my experience and feeling with facts and data. When I got serious with a second husband, if he didn't share that mindset, I would not have proceeded. I am so much happier and so much less angry in my second relationship. Patricia - Concord, NH: A book that changed the way I look at the world was ["Stones From the River" by Ursula Hegi](https://www.simonandschuster.com/books/Stones-from-the-River/Ursula-Hegi/9780684844770). It's a book about Germany between the wars, and it shows how little steps become big steps and lead into the Holocaust. And it just went bit by bit. I think that this is a book that most people should read to understand history. And of course, as we all want to keep from repeating it. Matt - Hollis, NH: I would answer that question by talking about a book called ["Chasing the Scream" by Johann Hari](https://chasingthescream.com/). It's a book that goes into addiction, and how the war on drugs that was started many, many years ago has really not been adequate to try and fix the drug problem that we have in this country. And it offers very compelling data on some other places that have done it very differently. I think the other main point of the book is that people that are using drugs often are wanting to get off of them, and they just struggle to do it so much because there just aren't the support services that they need. I'm a physician and one of my specialties is critical care medicine, and we end up seeing a lot of drug addicts that end up in the intensive care unit who have overdosed. Over the course of my life and my career, my outlook on these patients has changed just so dramatically, both just from my personal experience, but also related to reading this book. Aubrey - Concord, NH: A book that influenced how I see the world is ["Braiding Sweetgrass" by Robin Wall Kimmerer](https://milkweed.org/book/braiding-sweetgrass). And I think it changed how I think about gratitude and how I think about reciprocity. I think it changed how I parent, in that I'm trying always to have my kids think about how they can be grateful for what we have, and the other beings who provide so much for us on this earth. Michelle - Keene, NH: The book that changed the way I think about the world was ["David and the Phoenix" [by David Ormondroyd]](https://www.simonandschuster.com/books/David-and-the-Phoenix/David-Ormondroyd/9781625580191)... I read it when I was about six. And it's because it opened the world of reading to me. I would not be the person that I am if I didn't love reading and go to reading for knowledge and entertainment. Sheila - Jaffrey, NH: The book that changed the way I think about the world is [‚ÄúThe Bear‚Äù by Andrew Krivak](https://www.andrewkrivak.com/book/the-bear/). He spent his summers here in Jaffrey‚Ä¶ It brought a whole nother level of feeling and understanding about this area, and a connection to the land that I hadn't really felt before. I've spent a good deal of my life here. I spent all my summers as a kid in Jaffrey, and so the land means a lot to me and the mountain means a lot to me. And the place where I live right now has a spectacular view of the mountain, so I feel really close to it. So the story is pretty much centered around a father and daughter who are the only ones left on the planet, apparently, or the only humans. And then there's this bear that shows up. So it's quite an amazing story, and because I've been, most of my life‚Ä¶ living close to the land and having connections with bears [it] has also meant a lot to me to connect with that. Bill - Peterborough, NH: I read a book called [‚ÄúPassing Strange‚Äù by Martha Sandweiss](https://www.penguinrandomhouse.com/books/296953/passing-strange-by-martha-a-sandweiss/9780143116868/readers-guide/), which completely changed my reading habits. It is a biography of Clarence King, who was the first head of the U.S. Geological Survey, and he was an interesting man. He led a secret life‚Ä¶ He lived as a Black man in spite of being a blue-eyed blond. And after reading this, I couldn't think of any other piece of fiction that I really cared about very much. This was so amazingly different. Mary - NH: One of my favorite books was called [‚ÄúThe Hands of My Father,‚Äù](https://www.myronuhlberg.com/hands_of_my_father__a_hearing_boy__his_deaf_parents__and_the_language_of_love_78814.htm) and it was written by Myron Uhlberg. And his parents were born deaf and his first language was American Sign Language as a child. And I was drawn to the book because it started in 30s, 40s Brooklyn, where I was born. And his father eventually was trained to be a printer, which was my father's occupation‚Ä¶ He started it as a child, and his father was deaf. He had to interpret when his father needed, you know, a document filled out or all those kinds of things‚Ä¶ I've read this book probably 15 years ago, but I can still invoke that feeling I got when I read the book. And also, I'm a nurse of many years, and whenever I have a patient who's hearing impaired or deaf, I really feel empathy for them and really try very hard to make their experience as fulfilling and as accurate and as attentive that I need to. It has really changed how I look at people with disabilities and it's changed the way I react to that. It was a very profound book for me.
